title: member one britains notorious neighbours
story: Member of notorious neighbour from hell family dies of Covid in prisonJohn Pitt, whose family were known as Britains worst "neighbours from hell" after hitting the headlines in the s, died as he served a jail sentence at HMP Humber, east YorkshireJohn Pitt, whose family were known as Britains worst neighbours from hell Image: Hull Daily Mail   MEN MediaByHarry Ingham:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A member of one of Britainaposs most notorious families has died in prison after catching Covid.John Pitt, whose family were known as Britainaposs worst neighbours from hell after hitting the headlines in the s, died as he served a jail sentence at HMP Humber in east Yorkshire. An official report said Mr Pitt died aged  after falling victim to a huge Covid outbreak at the prison near South Cave on the outskirts of Hull.Mr Pitt died of Covid- on March , , aged .Hull Live reports that Mr Pitt, who was a serial criminal with a history of violence, had served almost eight years more than his original sentence after he was jailed for attacking a former partner.A judge had described him as an obvious and gross continuing danger to the public. Mr Pittaposs partner had been tied up naked and threw herself ft from a window to escape him when he attacked her out of the blue at their home in Northumberland, trying to gouge her eyes out and threatening to cut her throat with scissors.  In July , Mr Pitt was given a minimum four-and-a half year imprisonment for public protectionsentence for  imprisonment. He was moved to HMP Humber in . An independent investigation by the Prisons and Probations Ombudsman has found that Mr Pitt caught the disease in the prison during a apossignicant outbreakapos in February and March . The ombudsman said she was concerned that when Mr Pitt tested positive for Covid-, healthcare staff did not take his clinical observations and he was not monitored to seehe became symptomatic. Mr Pitt was obese, which meant that he was at a higher risk of developing complications, and should have been closely monitored and his observations taken regularly, the report says. Mr Pitt complained about being unwell on March  but was told by a nurse to sit down to improve his breathing. The nurse then said they wouldto check on him later. But the report said Mr Pittaposs condition and risk “should have prompted an urgent clinical response. The nurse did notfor over an hour, by which time Mr Pitt had got into bed because he felt so unwell, and then an ambulance was called”.  At hospital, Mr Pitt’s health deteriorated, and he was admitted to intensive care unit where he was put on a ventilator. He died almost three weeks later. The report said there were also concerns Mr Pitt’s diabetes was not monitored regularly and there were no follow up checks or reviews documented in his clinical record. Mr Pitt had a violent le along with an extensive criminal record, including numerous counts of assault, criminal damage, and drug dealing. The report said he was the sixth prisoner at HMP Humber to die since March , with one more having died since. Of the other deaths, one was drug-related, two were self-inflicted and three were from Covid-. Jailing him in , Mr Justice Openshaw described Mr Pitt’s criminal record as “appalling”, Chronicle Live reported. title: mum thought pregnancy headaches before
story: Mum thought she had pregnancy headaches before doctors made devastating diagnosisDominique Nicholson, from Leicester, had a three-week-old newborn, Erin, when she was given the heartbreaking news that her severe headaches were due to a grade  atypical meningioma brain tumourA mum was devastated to discover her pregnancy headaches were actually a brain tumour Image: DOMINIQUE NICHOLSON   CATERS NEWSByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar |comments A mum was devastated to discover her pregnancy headaches were actually a brain tumour. Dominique Nicholson had a three week old newborn, Erin, when she was given the heartbreaking news that her severe headaches - which she claims were dismissed for months whilst pregnant - were down to a grade  atypical meningioma brain tumour. The -year-old from Leicester underwent surgery to have % of the mass removed just weeks after giving birth. She was so frightened that she even wrote goodbye letters to her young daughters, Erin, now two, and Freya, now six. The mum-of-two said she was left feeling numb at discovering the real reason behind her severe headaches, but that maternal instinct to watch her daughters grow up kept her determined to survive.After undergoing craniotomy surgery in July , she is now in recovery and has yearly checks. Dominique, who is sharing her story to raise awareness, said: I had headaches when I was pregnant with my first daughter, Freya. So when I had headaches with Erin, I wasnapost concerned, I assumed it was a mix of the stress of having a young child, working, being pregnant and generally tired. I mentioned my headaches to my midwe around five times, but she agreed there was no cause for concern and I assumed once I had given birth they would ease. However, after Dominique gave birth the headaches continued to get worse.  She said: I was emptying the dishwasher and as I bent down, the pressure behind my eyes was intense and I fell to the floor in agony. My head was throbbing and when my husband, David, now , came home we went to the hospital. Dominique, a licensing conveyancer, was sent for a CT scan but couldnapost process the diagnosis. She said: Erin was just three weeks old and I expected to be told it was severe migraines.When the doctor explained it was a mass on the brain, I was in shock and very scared. My first thought was my girls. I had to see my daughters grow up. It was my maternal inner strength that got me through the surgery - my biggest fear was not waking up.Dominique wrote goodbye letters to her daughters before undergoing craniotomy surgery to remove all but a small percentage of the tumour which was wrapped around a major blood vessel. She said: I spent a lot of time sobbing in hospital. I needed to put things in place, so I wrote letters, arranged godparents and thought about things to help Davidsomething went wrong in surgery. I distracted myself as much as I could, preparing things for Dave in case I wasnapost there. Thankfully the surgery was a success and without complications and Dominique was able to go home soon afterwards. A biopsy revealed it was a grade two atypical meningioma. She added: I was diagnosed, operated on and home within seven days. There was a bit left attached to a blood vessel that was too dangerous to move but as I was breastfeeding Erin doctors knew that my recovery would be quicker at home. I needed to be with my family.  Dominique was left with a cm scar across her forehead and down the right-hand side of her face. She said: The scar was so much bigger than I expected and I tried to hide it from my eldest and bought headscarves. The scar was mentally hard to come to terms with and I can still feel the scars now. I also saw a counsellor as it was a lot to deal with. I spent a long time hiding inside when my face was at its worst, but gradually I made little outings to regain my confidence. I consider myself to be so lucky and I am grateful to be alive. I now have annual scans to checkthe tumour has come back. It is worrying to think it may come back and that does cause me a lot of anxietyI get a headache. The married couple have been together for  years and are looking forward to celebrating their -year wedding anniversary later this year.  Now the family are focused on raising as much awareness - and funding - as possible. She said: The Brain Tumour Charity is incredible and I just want to get as much awareness out as possible. I am running  miles to represent the  types of brain tumours that exist. I am very lucky to have been treated so quickly and I donapost like to think about what could have happenedI didnapost. I want to warn everyone - but especially mums and expectant mums not to put their own health last. You know your own body and what is normal andsomething isnapost right push for answers. My headaches were ongoing, I felt sick and I was forgetting things. If that sounds like you, please go to your doctor. title: ordinary three bed terraced home
story: Ordinary three-bed terraced home hides incredible PALACE in living roomThe terraced home with  bedrooms is located in Christchurch, Dorset and was listed on the market on TuesdayA -bedroom property with a palatial Roman-style living room has been listed on the market for £,ByRuaraidh GilmourLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar |commentsA three-bed property with a palatial Roman-style living room has been listed on the market for £,. The terraced home in Christchurch, Dorset was listed on the market on Tuesday March . The large living room takes up over half of the downstairs and its main feature is a detailed ceiling painting that depicts angels flying and sitting on clouds. The depiction is bordered with round gold and blue trim with ious patterns.  A bust of a woman stands tall at the back of the room, while gold trimmed patterned chairs and couches are positioned next to the light blue walls. There is a marble coffee table that sits on an old fashioned royal-looking carpet whilst a large gold rimmed mirror hangs on the back wall. Breaking the Roman theme, there is a flat screen TV hung from the wall and a guitar amplier resting on one of the chairs.  Leaving the lavish room, the rest of the house appears to be far more common. The kitchen is of a good size and has a double glass door that leads to the garden. Two of the three bedrooms are of good size and can comfortably accommodate double beds, while the third room could only fit a single bed.  The only bathroom in the property is situated upstairs and has a large bath and a separate shower. In their listing on Rightmove, Goadsby, who are managing the property wrote: A spacious terraced home situated in a popular area being just yards from Two Riversmeet Leisure Centre with its golf course. Christchurch town centre is also easily accessible.  There is a covered entrance porch which has a storage cupboard, a door leads through to the lounge. The lounge is a good size with a front aspect window. A door leads through to the kitchen breakfast room which has ample space for a dining table whilst also having a good range of wall and floor cupboards with working surfaces over... There are  doubles, both having fitted cupboards and Bedroom  is currently used as an office.  The bathroom benefits from a corner bath with separate shower cubicle, pedestal wash hand basin and low level w.c. One social media user saw the unique living room and decided to share it on Reddit: For just £k you can enjoy the wonders of the Sistine Chapel from the comfort of your own living room. The post has over  likes and has been commented on over a dozen times.Reddit users found the living room amusing.@Grumpyandproud said: I was not prepared for that living room. @Keiepse wrote: aposThe lounge is a good size with a front aspect window.aposAmazing that the agent couldnapost think of anything  for the description. @Leftpillz commented: Itaposs a pretty appropriate design given the cityaposs name, Christchurch. @Nicowltan replied: That living room is insane, but Iaposm a big fan of the dog at the back door.@busyphil added: Wow. I love the way the description doesnapost reference that ceiling at all. title: pandemic heroes can help level
story: Pandemic heroes can help us level up country and bring communities togetherWe are days away now from the second anniversary of lockdown. Two years on, we have seen communities come together, neighbours look out for one other and groups form across the UKCharles Burrell Centre manager Nik Chapman, outside the centre in Thetford Image: MATTHEW USHERByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnistClaire Donnelly:,  Mar |comments At the peak of the pandemic, on the Henley Green estate in Coventry, residents got used to the sight of two top-of-the-range Jaguars delivering food.The local community centre had turned its ‘Grub Hub service’ into a delivery service for isolating residents. As it grew from  members to supporting , people, they had asked local business for support. “Jaguar Land Rover let us use two of their vehicles,” says Dianne Williams, , CEO of the Moat House Trust. “We went out delivering meals in these two white jags. It was brilliant.”We are days away now from the second anniversary of lockdown. Two years on, we have seen communities come together, neighbours look out for one other and groups form across the UK. Never mind that – to use words of one campaigning organisation – we were led by donkeys. The British public were lions – acting as a pride. This week, the Mirror has been celebrating working class solidarity and community spirit after revisiting our  Wigan Pier Project journey. Now, we are paying tribute to those who stepped up during the pandemic. From the Knowle West Alliance who fed people in Bristol, to an advice delivery service in Berwick-on-Tweed, to the Levy Corona Helpers in Manchester’s Levenshulme and Centre in Grimsby, this was a national effort carried out at grassroots level. Hyper-local micro-miracles that have changed the face of Britain. Over , mutual aid groups – modelled on systems of support used by black radicals in America – provided solidarity, not charity, supported by a staggering three million volunteers. Existing community projects transformed their provision. Trade unions turned out volunteers, as well as getting workers furloughed and preventing redundancies.  The Mirror teamed up with the Red Cross for a Kindness Will Keep Us Together campaign and more than , signed up. From driving people to hospital appointments to delivering essential medicines, more than , acts of kindness were carried out across the country in just the first four months of lockdown.More than , people signed up to the NHS volunteer scheme. In the first three weeks of lockdown, , people signed up to become community volunteers. More than , people donated their time in  to support the vaccine rollout.Groups formed to help with food shopping and food parcels, collecting prescriptions and providing dog walking. They helped tackle loneliness, were a source of trustworthy Covid information, set up community gardens, and much more. But most importantly, in dark times, every act of kindness was a beacon of hope. The Charles Burrell Centre in Thetford, Norfolk, became a hub for mutual aid that has never ended. “We had a lady in this week enquiring about eligibility for fuel voucher,” Nik Chapman, CEO of The Charles Burrell Centre in Thetford, says. “In the last eight weeks, she only switched her heating on for Christmas Day and had been eating all food cold. She has been making extreme decisions to stay out of debt.”  The Centre provides a supermarket, a community fridge, a hygiene and a fuel bank – services accessed by around , people. “It’s not just about any food,” Nik says. “We need to combat diabetes, obesity and rickets. Le expectancy in this part of Thetford is  to  years less than the more affluent parts. Part of that is nutrition.” He adds: “% of the people who come are employed – a lot work at local supermarkets but they can’t afford to shop there.” Some  miles away in London, the Manor House Development Trust realised many families were unable to home school because they had no internet access. “People would usually come to our spaces to use the wi, but during the pandemic we couldn’t do that,” CEO Simon Donovan, , says. So, they crowdfunded to get residents old and young online. They delivered art packs to kelp kids learning and connected knitters and sewers who got to work making PPE. More than  volunteers gave out , pre-cooked meals to local residents – , kilos of food. Two years on, some Mutual Aid groups have already pivoted to help refugees from Afghanistan, and now Ukraine – putting our government to shame. Meanwhile, the crisis after the pandemic is only just beginning. Vulnerable families face rocketing bills. Many are far worse off than when they were furloughed, while others have lost the £ pandemic uplt to Universal Credit.This incredible network of local groups stands poised to help – but it faces its own challenges, from volunteer burn out to a lack of footfall in charity shops and cafes. Locality – which supports local community organisations – will publish a new report next week that will argue government should put communities in charge of its levelling up funding – including the Community Ownership Fund and UK Shared Prosperity Fund. “Two years ago, an amazing thing happened,” Tony Armstrong, chief exec of Locality, says. “At our hour of need, we looked to each other for help and rediscovered the awesome power of community. Now government, funders and other decision-makers must put their faith in these organisations and give them the powers and resources to get on with the job. There can be no levelling up without powering up community organisations everywhere.”  Done properly, what happened during the pandemic can be a blueprint for Levelling Up. Instead of reinventing the wheel with top-down, eye-catching schemes, the government should strengthen existing community-led projects. “I think we all know it is going to get worse,” Nik Chapman says. “The cost of pretty much everything is rocketing. Undoubtedly the tragedy in Ukraine will have an impact. It’s a crisis. But at least we can be there to say, ‘it’s not going to be alright, but at least you’re not alone’.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSRed CrossHospitalsChristmas shoppingSupermarketsCoronavirusDaily Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: pub owner says two families
story: Pub owner says two families left venue like bomb site without paying £ billThe spokesperson for the White Horse Inn venue on Barnby Moor, in East Retford, said the four adults and their children were "intimidating" to the staff during their stayThe pub owner said the families left the place looking like a bomb site Image: White Horse InnByOlimpia Zagnat:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A devastated pub owner claims two families left his venue like a bomb site without paying their £ bill.The spokesperson for the White Horse Inn venue on Barnby Moor, in East Retford, said the four adults and their children arrived at the restaurant at around .pm, and were intimidating to the staff during their stay.They ordered tomahawk steaks, cocktails, vodka and drinks for their four children which rounded up to an impressive £.However, they reportedly vanished at around pm without paying. A spokesperson for the venue said this could not come at a worse time, as the business is still recovering from the Covid lockdown.He told Nottinghamshire Live: It is just ridiculous. One of them distracted the member of staff by standing at the bar out of sight of the door. He was ordering another drink while the ladies in the group marched their children out, one under each arm, and bundled them into a couple of cars. Then they waited until the last guy exited and shot off. He went on and said: We started the business in , just before Covid hit, and so obviously it is a dficult time. The price of everything is going up massively. We have got wholesale beer increases of nearly p a pint this year to deal with. We are going to try to soak that all up, and we will try and fight all of that and then people are going to do that. It is not very helpful.  He said that while the incident hit the venue from a business perspective, it is the well-being of members of the staff that he is more concerned about. He added: The member of the staff that was on rang the manager and said he was upset and quite exasperated. He had been intimidated by their passive-aggressive behaviour - and he has blamed himself. It is awful because he was doing really well and was training to be in a managerial position. Now he has lost all of his confidence. It is not that it just hurts my pocket, the real problem is that the staff there are nervous now and do not feel comfortable.  The pub owner said that he has worked in the industry for about a decade - but that he has never witnessed anything like it. He added: The children were running around the restaurant, running up to peopleaposs tables, falling over things. And then they have left bowls of food upturned on the floor - I have never seen anything like it in ten years in the industry. It was just like a pack of bears had been in.Inspector Hayley Crawford, of Nottinghamshire Police, said: “We are pursuing lines of enquiry following a report that a group of people had attended The White Horse Inn in Barnby Moor, eaten a meal and left without paying.“Officers are making enquiries after the incident was reported to us at around pm yesterday. “To help us with our investigation we are urging anyone with information to please get in touch with us.” It is believed those involved left the area in a white van and a black car. More than , people have watched the clip, with it garnering over , likes. Dozens of users have also commented on the video, with many sharing that they didnapost know about the packaging and that the aposfun factapos made lots of sense. A third said: Broooo….that’s so smart and I always wondered how they went so effing fast. Someone  posted: Also most types of packaging have barcodes in the same relative areas. story: Hiker finds Bigfoot proof as experts say print is definitely not from a bearInternet users have been debating over a possible Bigfoot footprint found by a hiker, with several Sasquatch enthusiasts ruling out the possibility of a bear or a humanA hiker believes they have found proof of Bigfoots existence Image: Getty ImagesByJohn BettAudience WriterEthan Blackshaw:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A hiker believes they have found fresh proof of Bigfoot and experts agree that the footprint clearly isnapost a bear. Sharing the image anonymously, the hiker posted a snap of the imprint on Reddit and said they found it while hiking in Calornia, as the Daily Star reports.He said he found it at the top of a hike in Big Sur, a mountain range between Carmel and San Simeon, and people believe it could be evidence of a genuine sasquatch. The image shows a clear and deep foot imprint in some mud, and several people in the forum agreed that the print definitely didnapost come from a bear. What do you think about the sighting  Let us know in the comments...One Reddit user wrote: This is the first imprint I have seen that isnapost clearly a bear. Good find! I wish the print was fresher but this really does look more like a Bigfoot track. I donapost notice the double step of a bear. It could have been human but I donapost notice tread marks or shoe marks. Another said: Definitely Sasquatch. The upper foot impression is relative to the lower width and diameter of the depth. Iaposd reach out to the local BFRSO [Bigfoot Field Researchers Organisation] in your area asap. What a solid print, added a third. However, other Bigfoot enthusiasts werenapost as convinced by the original posteraposs find, arguing that it was probably just a human boot print. It’s a booted boot print. Next to a weirdly socked foot, one person joked.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. Another wrote: Looks just like a washed-out boot print. A third said: It doesnapost look crazy large compared to your foot, at least -wise, which makes me lean towards human. But they then backtracked and added: It is oddly wide though, and thereaposs no tread I can see. The ground doesnapost look too conducive for capturing fine details, but youaposd still expect some evidence of tread somewhere in the track. story: Little girl with beautul voice made the world weep for children of UkraineThere has never been a more powerful version of Let It Go, Polly Hudson says of the footage from an underground bunker, reminding us how lives have been turned upside down for millions of innocentsAmelia singing in the bunker Image: PAopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Mar |commentsIt’s the chaos surrounding her that you notice first. The ­desperate families squeezed in, standing, sitting, lying wherever they can, next to their precariously piled ­belongings, packed into the dank underground space they now call home. There’s an air of restlessness, a palpable sense of tension and anxiety. How could there not be And then, completely unexpectedly, something magical happens. Little Amelia – age unknown, but probably, what, seven or eight  – stands up on a chair. She’s wearing a sparkly jumper with stars on it, from HM a few years ago – my friend’s daughter has the same one and still loves it too. Hands clenched together shyly, unbrushed hair pulled back into a ponytail, Amelia plucks up all her courage, opens her mouth and starts to sing Let It Go, from Frozen. And like a spell cast in the movie her song comes from, the Kyiv shelter falls silent. Everyone turns and gives this small blonde scrap of a girl their mesmerised full attention. No one moves. Babies stop crying. This captive audience cannot take their eyes off her, as they listen to her sweet, steady voice, a chink of shining light in the unimaginable ­darkness of Ukraine.She has given these people the gt of focusing on something other than the living nightmare they’re enduring, albeit briefly, and there isn’t a dry eye in the room. Or from any of the millions around the globe who have since watched the video on social media.Despite probably never having heard Ukrainian before, the song is in the universal language of Disney, kids from any country in the world watching it could name that tune in three. In the caption, the woman who posted it explains that Amelia told her she wanted to be “a singer on a grand stage” – an ambition now fulfilled, just not in a way anyone would want. Their poor parents can, at least, try to fight back, but the children of Ukraine are utterly defenceless in this war. Putin is torturing and traumatising these pure, faultless human beings, turning them into orphans. Murdering  of them.  Amelia and the other kids in that shelter, and similar ones across the country. Danya and Mpak, the boys trapped in Calais, denied entry by our callous government because they don’t have the right paperwork. The -year-old who braved a -mile journey to safety alone. Heroic President Volodymyr Zelensky’ s own children – Aleksandra, , and Kiril, age nine – who have targets on their backs. Polina, the girl with the pink hair, and her brother Semyon, both dead. And the many other nameless young casualties.All entirely blameless, innocent children – just like their entirely blameless, innocent mums and dads – frightened for their lives.  Two weeks ago they were moaning about homework, playing with their friends, not eating their vegetables. Now, suddenly plunged into a reality where growing up without their fathers may well be the best case scenario. The least worst of their horrendous options. When Let It Go lyricist Kristen Anderson-Lopez saw Amelia’s rendition, she tweeted: “Dear Little Girl with the beautul voice, my husband and I wrote this song. The way you sing it is like a magic trick that spreads the light in your heart and heals everyone who hears it.” She finished by urging Amelia to “Keep singing!” If only that choice was hers. story: Man called Little John who lives in a cave sees his dad for first time in  yearsThe -year-old lives in a cave in Otago, New Zealand performs dentistry on himself and doesnt collect any benefit to surviveLittle John, who has lived in a cave for a decade, has been reunited with his dad after  years Image: stuff.co.nzByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar |commentsA man called aposLittle Johnapos who has lived in a cave for the last decade has been reunited with his dad for the first time in  years. The -year-old, who lives out in Otago on New Zealandaposs South Island, lives an extraordinary le which involves performing dentistry on himself and not collecting any benefit to survive. There was no particular animosity or argument in the family that broke them apart - but the separation came after the death of Little Johnaposs brother which hit everyone very hard. Little John was battling addictions and watched the collapse of his relationship - and thataposs when he moved out to live in the cave. And he hasnapost moved for the last  years. After publication Stuff shared Little Johnaposs story, his family, including his sister based in Australia, got in touch saying they were so grateful for the words about him.Little Johnaposs sister said: It feels like a weight has been lted, no longer fearing the worst and wondering where he was. It also caused his father, who Stuff agreed not to name and who is based in Dunedin, New Zealand, to contact a foodbank to try to track him down. Michelle Kerr, from the Mosgiel Community Foodbank, told  News it was a huge step for him. Little John explained that he knew his fatheraposs address but hadnapost visited him since he moved to the South.  But on Wednesdaythe father and son were finally reunited after  years apart. Little Johnaposs dad said it was a wonderful experience. The pair enjoyed a meal and spent quality time together - Little John even spoke to his sister in Australia. Little John even found out his mother had died in . The father and son decided they plan to see each other again in the future.  Living several kilometers away from the closest human structure, Little John said itaposs there that he found peace with God and became close with his fellow Christians.Little John himself said the Stuff article had helped him too as he has been able to form bonds with local residents. Where previously they were wary of picking him up, he can now hitchhike. And a few weeks ago Little John said he heard people calling his name who had obviously gone looking for him. Struggling to find his cave at first, they began calling his name, to which he replied Gaposday. Little John said he had had some offers from hopeful aposcave womenapos, but not as many as he wanted. He particularly likes the cold months in the Otago caves and plans to spend winter there. Explaining why he lives in the cave he said for me itaposs natural, and natural is healthy.  He also doesnapost want to claim the unemployment benefit or eventually the pension because he said the money would give him access to his addictions. Little John explained heaposs always had a problem with booze and smokes but now he smokes and drinks much less basically because he canapost afford it. He has given up on Government support, come off the dole and closed his bank account in what he describes as a really big step. Doing odd jobs and using food banks, he gets by on around  a year. Little John added that he lives in a cave because itaposs free but also because nobody bugs him there. story: Russian forces advance on Kyiv with troops within three miles of citys outskirtsA -mile long convoy of Russian tanks has been slowly advancing towards the capital as ambush attempts and shelling have been seen on the outskirtsA member of the Ukrainian Territorial Defence Forces keeps watch in central Kyiv Image: REUTERSByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsVladimir Putinaposs troops are inching closer and closer to Kyiv as the battle for the capital is underway. The Russian military is now believed to be just three miles from the cityaposs limits, a senior US defence official said. A -mile long convoy of Russian tanks has been slowly advancing towards the capital as ambush attempts and shelling have been seen on the outskirts. Russian troops launched two attacks in the area - one in the western city of Irpin and another on the east side of Broy. Video of the attack in Boy shows Russian tanks being ambushed with heavy artillery before turning back. Colonel Andrei Zakharov, commander of the tank regiment, was also killed in the ambush according to the Ukrainian defence ministry.Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News Bulletin here Vadym Denysenko, an adviser to Ukraineaposs interior ministry, said his forces also stopped the attack in Irpin. In an update today, the Ukrainian military said it had stopped Russiaaposs attempt to cross the Irpin River in the town of Moshchun. Denysenko said: The night was quite dficult, but in general we can say that the Ukrainian army counterattacked near Kyiv. Follow all todayaposs latest updates on the conflict with our live blog  There is no further detailed information yet. Putinaposs efforts to surround the capital continued today as more fighting has been reported on the southwest side of Kyiv. A full-scale assault on the Ukrainian capital could be on the horizon as there are fears Putin could launch similar airstrikes as he did on the city of Mariupol and Kharkiv. In Mariupol, a maternity hospital was hit and killed three, including a six-year-old girl. President Volodymyr Zelensky, who is still in Kyiv, today said his heart breaks at what the occupants have done with our cities, our country, and at what they want to do to our people,who he said needed urgent help.Kyiv mayor Vitali Klitschko said today that the capital has been turned into a fortress ahead of the Russian assault. He said in televised remarks: Every street, every house is being fortied, the territorial defence is joining. Even people who in their lives never intended to change their clothes, now they are in unorm with machine guns in their hands. Troops are warning civilians not to stray beyond the outskirts of the city because Russian vehicles had been spotted just a few miles away.  If Putinaposs troops encircle Kyiv, they could shell it as they have done to Mariupol, Kharkiv and Chernihiv. Ukrainian officials say Mariupol continues to be surrounded by Russian forces but is still in Ukrainian control. They said Ukrainian fighter jets and anti-aircraft missile units destroyed four Russian Su- attack jets and two Russian helicopters over the past  days.It comes as chilling photos from Mariupol showing corpses being discarded in mass grave sites as the death toll in the city grows.This week it was revealed more than , people have died in the port city, formerly the home of nearly half a million people, since the start of the Russian invasion.Described by rescuers as a humanitarian crisis, authorities have ordered workers to dig  metre long trenches as morgues are at breaking point.In tragic scenes, they were seen making the sign of the cross as the dead- wrapped in an old carpet- are pushed into the makesht mass graves.  Forty bodies were dumped in the trench in the cemetery on Tuesday, followed by  more on Wednesday. They were said to be both civilians and soldiers No family members were seen at the gravesite to say goodbye to their loved ones. Ukraine estimates that Russia has lost some , troops in the fighting, along with  tanks, , armoured personnel carriers,  vehicles,  helicopters and  planes.Moscow has not given an accurate figure. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: march gardening tips it starts with a seed
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIn a week or two it will be March, which will hopefully bring some sunny days to tempt gardeners back into the garden # and many of us are really aching for spring now.This is the month for sowing seeds and getting the garden ready for the summer.But, before you rush to get sowing, take time to plan what you want to grow, how many plants you are going to need and when you want them to flower or bear fruit. This is particularly good advice for anyone with a veg plot.A sowing plan of what seeds and how many to sow each month is key to successful growing and means you won#t be throwing out unwanted seedlings and that your flower and veg beds will be full all year round.A word of warning about sowing direct into the ground at this time of year there may be a few sunny days to enjoy outside but the soil can still be chilly, making germination and survival hard.Sowing indoors is a better option. Not only does it provide a warm environment for germination, but seeds and seedlings are easier to protect from pests. If you can find some environmentally sound sowing trays and containers, rather than using plastic, that#s even better. Paper and cardboard pots can be packed snugly in a tray which avoids over handling and makes them easy to water.Small seeds should be scattered sparingly on the surface of compost filled seed trays then covered with a sprinkling of sieved compost. If the seeds are big enough to handle, you can sow them inidually into cm pots. The quantity should be according to the instructions specied on the seed packet, but usually for small seeds between five and  seeds per pot. For plants that grow long roots, such as peas or beans, you can put them into a compost filled cardboard toilet roll tube and, once ready, they can be planted outside, tube and all.Most seeds will germinate and grow in a warm setting such as a greenhouse, cold frame or on a sunny windowsill. You should keep them damp by using a mist spray to start with before moving onto a watering can with a fine rose nozzle.Once the seedlings have grown their second pair of leaves and before they get too squashed in seed trays or pots, pot them on into small pots. Simply ease out a clump of seedlings with an old cutlery fork or dibber and # handling only the leaves to avoid damaging delicate stems and roots # gently tease them apart. Drop inidual seedlings into a five-centimetre compost filled newspaper pot ensuring the lower leaves are above the compost level. Once you see roots appearing from the bottom of the pot, it’s time to pot on to a bigger pot before planting outside once the weather and soil warms up.If you are growing your own veg, now is a good time to sow first early potatoes. These can be planted from mid-March, however planting times will y across the country according to temperature and risk of frost. Early potatoes grow well in the ground and in containers such as potato grow bags or old compost bags. You should plant your chitted potatoes with the shoots facing upwards in soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter, approximately cms deep and cms apart.Once stems are about cms tall, they will need earthing up by drawing soil around them to create a cm high ridge, to protect against frost and keep growing potatoes covered. Good ieties of early potatoes are: Swt # good for containers, white skinned and white fleshed Annabelle # nutty flavour with firm waxy yellow flesh and Maris Bard # white flesh with good #new potato# flavour and drought resistance.Spring seems tantalisingly close in March, particularly as work in the garden starts to get going again.According to the Royal Horticultural Society, spring usually arrives by mid-March and the frequent sunny days provide the opportunity for an increasing range of gardening tasks. It#s time to get busy preparing seed beds, sowing seed, cutting back winter shrubs and generally tidying up around the garden.Top three jobs in March:PICS:Once the seedlings have grown their second pair of leaves and before they get too squashed in seed trays or pots, pot them on into small pots. no_aGardening_March

your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowInveraray History Society took a walk on the wild side at its latest meeting as Argyll Estates# head stalker set his sights on an entertaining evening.Tom Kirsop provided society members with an informative and imaginative talk at their February gathering, covering his work and experiences on the local estate.Growing up in Clydebank, Tom had always had an interest in animals and moved to Argyll as a forest ranger in Dalmally.Since starting to work with Argyll Estates, which he thoroughly enjoys, Tom has been able to develop his work with animals in many dferent ways.In Queen Victoria’s time the current ,-acre estate was on an even bigger scale and has witnessed a huge increase in the number of deer since then.This has been due to the lack of any natural predators and, with further planting of trees since the s, the deer have had more protective covering.Modern inventions such as drones and the use of argocats, have made it easier for people working on estates to estimate numbers of deer more accurately and to be able to meet the necessary annual targets of keeping the deer population to manageable levels.Working on the estate also involves a range of other projects, such as collecting data on golden eagles, barn owls, making fishing available at the Glen Shira dam and taking clients out stalking.More recently Tom has started up West Highland Wildle Tours to give people of all ages a real insight into the wildle and beautul scenery on our doorstep.For the society#s March meeting, Ken MacTaggart will give a presentation about #The Medieval Pilgrim Way to Loch Awe#.The venue will be Inveraray church hall on Tuesday March , starting at .pm.Everyone is welcome. Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowMid Argyll under-s travelled to Old Anniesland to play in the rearranged West Youth Cup Tie against GHK.The weather in Glasgow was perfect on Sunday February  and the pitch was in great condition # ideal for attacking rugby.With some players unavailable and after a few late call-offs the boys travelled with just  players, but confidence was high with theof influential forwards Euan MacArthur and captain Donald Self.The clubs agreed to play  Vs  and Mid Argyll had to field a rearranged pack with William Wilson stepping up to play in the front row and Lucas Gritten joining MacArthur in the second row.The game started well, with both teams competing for every ball. GHK broke the deadlock to score the first try of the game  minutes into the game, then missed the conversion.Mid Argyll then put together some great attacking plays and earned a penalty just outside the GHK -metre line.Inside centre Coll MacKay stepped up to score Mid Argyll#s first points of the campaign with a glorious conversion.  –  to GHK.GHK went on to score two more tries and one conversion # before disaster struck for Mid Argyll on the stroke of half time and with the score at  –  to GHK, as Wilson hobbled off with suspected knee ligament damage.With Wilson playing out of position in the front row, Mid Argyll had to reshuffle an already patchwork pack with Aaron McAllister moving from the wing to hooker and usual hooker Robbie Herd moving to prop.The new look front row finished off, Daniel Doherty doing well, as they held their own against an experienced opposition pack.Mid Argyll took time to settle into the new system, though, and GHK ran in two more converted tries.Mid Argyll almost produced the perfect reply when fly-half Logan Allen whipped a quick ball out to Gritten who, without actually catching the ball, flicked it on to Innes Patterson.Patterson beat two players and released Ed King-Venables who was caught by the GHK defence just short of the line.GHK ran the ball back up field but some great defensive play from flanker Gordon McLean, Self and MacArthur stopped them on the halfway line.A scrum to Mid Argyll saw scrum-half Calum Patterson pick the ball from the feet of McLean and, noticing a gap in the defence, broke through.He still had two more players to beat before he ran over the whitewash for Mid Argyll#s first try of the season # undoubtedly try of the match. MacKay converted for another two points and the score was  –  GHK.Having played with no subs, fatigue was starting to set in for the Argyll boys and with GHK using their subs they ran in a few more breakaway tries.Towards the end of the game GHK had one last attempt and broke through the Argyll defence, but from nowhere C Patterson found the determination and energy to chase the attacker down and fling out an arm to ankle tap him five metres short of the line and supporting was Lochlain Ellis to compete for the ball and earn Mid Argyll a deserved penalty.The final whistle sounded shortly after and the game finished  - to GHK.Mid Argyll enjoyed great hospitality from hosts GHK and Innes Patterson was awarded man of the match before the long journey home.

title: science matters another unwelcome invader 2
story: Dorothy H CrawfordUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowMost of us are active by day and rest by night, but within these confines there are several possibilities ranging from larksto owls .These preferences, called chronotypes, have a genetic basis that controls one#s biological clock, but this can be modied by ious factors such as light exposure, age and lestyle.However, when the genetic and environmental cues are not aligned a chronic condition known as #social jetlag# may ensue.This problem is exacerbated during adolescence when chronotypes become increasingly delayed, but schools start early in the morning.This can cause sleep loss that may lead to major health and psychological problems and also affect academic performance.In a recent study scientists examined how the interaction between chronotype and school start time influenced inidual academic performance* by taking advantage of a high school system where  students had been randomly assigned to lessons in the morning , afternoonor evening .This enabled the unbiased testing of the effect of chronology and school schedules on academic performance in adolescents aged - years and - years.The results showed that among the early morning group, very few students got adequate sleep.The larksoutperformed owlsin all school subjects and this effect, which increased as students progressed through the school, was most extreme in maths.This outcome, however, was not evident in those having afternoon schooling, and the situation almost reversed in those receiving evening schooling, where students with later chronotypes performed slightly better in languages than the early chronotypes in the same group.Clearly academic performance is influenced by biological iation in daily rhythms, to an extent that has previously been underestimated.The study authors, while conceding that it is impractical to attempt to fully align school timetables to inidual chronotypes, suggest that it may be possible to, for example, progressively delay school start times during adolescence.* Goldin et al.  https:doi.org . s---.

title: in columbas footsteps without cuban heels
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowA TV series will feature Mid Argyll as it follows seven celebrities on a pilgrimage through Ireland, Northern Ireland and Scotland.#Pilgrimage# follows the celebs # of dferent faiths and none # for  days as they follow in the footsteps of Saint Columba, seeking out his legacy as a key figure in early British Christianity, helping spread the faith from Ireland to Scotland and beyond.Along the way Will Bayley, Scarlett Moffat, Monty Panesar, Louisa Clein, Laurence Lewellyn-Bowen, Shazia Mirza and Nick Hewer enjoyed the hospitality of the people of Knapdale.They arrived in Achahoish on September  last year, having set off from Northern Ireland the previous day by boat.Tired and weary, the pilgrims were welcomed into South Knapdale Parish Church at Achahoish, where they met with some of the congregation and shared a meal.South Knapdale Parish Church Minister Reverend David Carruthers explained: #The programme#s producers # and the visitors # had caught wind of the fact that the church in Achahoish has been used previously by pilgrim groups passing through.#The Presbytery of Argyll#s youth workers have previously arranged pilgrim walks under the banner of the Columba Experience and the church at Achahoish was used for accommodation on two successive years.#After their meal at Achahoish, the group started to share with one another something of their backgrounds, beliefs and faiths whilst the TV cameras rolled.After three hours of fascinating chat, the locals went home and the travellers bedded down on the church floors in their sleeping bags.Next day the pilgrims headed northwards via Columba#s Cave near Ellary, where Father Simon MacKenzie of Christchurch in Lochgilphead conducted a short act of worship.The celebrity pilgrims began their journey in Donegal before travelling to Argyll. From Knapdale, they headed up the west coast, sailing to Lewis and Harris before arriving at their final destination, Iona.Covering almost , miles in the series, they visit places of worship, from pagan stones to an early Christian cave and a contemporary mosque and Sikh temple. The journey tests the pilgrims not just spiritually, but physically too.TV celeb and comedian Scarlett Moffatt, , said: #At school, I spent a lot of time just reading books and on my own and so that’s how I got into faith really. It just felt calming. There’s almost a stigma attached to sort of being religious.#Whenever I would tell my friends, they’d laugh and I’d be like, #why is that funny # I believe in God, there has to be something that started all this.#I would describe myself as Christian, but not a strict Christian. I don’t go to church, but I definitely believe and religion to me is security.#She added: #In my head somebody on a pilgrimage is in a loin cloth and they have really long hair#and they look a bit dehydrated like they need a good moisturiser mask.#I’m doing the pilgrimage as I want to know what my religion is. I want to be able to answer that question with confidence.#TV personality and interior designer Laurence Lewellyn-Bowen describes himself as a #non-conforming pagan#. The -year-old explained: #I think pilgrimage is about clearing out your mental closet by physical exertion and by spiritual conversation with yourself or,you believe it, then conversation with your God.#I know I come across as all sort of flouncy and floppy and rather cavalier, but I am capable of existing in the real world.#However, I don’t think I’ve walked so far not wearing Cuban heels.#Pilgrimage: The Road to the Scottish Isles will be screened on BBC Two and iPlayer in the spring with three one-hour-long episodes, and is a CTVC production.

title: france-currently-best-team-world-murrayfield-performance-suggests-yes
story: FRANCE lived up to the pre-match assessment of Scotland’s head coach Gregor Townsend as currently the best team in the world.BT Murrayfield was in fine voice as captain Rachel Malcolm and centre Helen Nelson – fresh from their - victory over Columbia in Dubai yesterday, which ensured qualication for the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand in October delivered the match ball.Melvyn Jaminet missed an early penalty due to the gusting winds, but the visitors were soon in the lead after Paul Willemse crashed over for a try which Jaminet converted.Straight from the restart, Hawick man Darcy Graham made an audacious mid-air catch and Scotland were soon on the board as Fin Russell kicked a penalty.Jaminet then took advantage of the new : kick rule and from the resultant pressure Yoram Moefana crash over for the visitors’ second try, the left wing scoring on the right. Jaminet missed the conversion.A challenge by Jaminet on Stuart McInally then had the Scots fans raging. Initially, referee Karl Dickson allowed play to continue but after checking with the TMO awarded Scotland a penalty and ruled that was sufficient sanction.Ali Price appeared to be over for Scotlands first try, in spite of a high tackle but the ball had not been grounded.Scotland were now camped in the French  and from Nick Haining’s surge, Price fed former Southern Knight Rory Darge who crashed over for his first try for Scotland on his first start. Russell converted.Scotland then missed a great chance when Chris Harris threw a miss-two pass to Stuart Hogg but, agonisingly the ball spilled it forward and a golden try chance was lost for Scotland.Just before the break France extended their lead when Fickou beat the tackles of Price and Haining to touch down at the corner flag and Jaminet converted from the touchline.France extended their lead shortly after the break when a kick forward bounced awkwardly into the path of Jonathan Danty who ran in for the bonus point try. Jaminet grabbed the extras..removePenaud then romped in for try number five and although Jaminet missed the conversion everyone knew the game was lost.France added a sixth try in  minutes after Romain Ntamack’s cross-field kick, found Penaud who had a simple task.Scotland did pull back a try at the death after Blair Kinghorn’s break was rounded off by van der Merwe, who dotted down his tenth try for his country. Hogg converted.But it was too little to late for the Scots and the French ran out - winners.

title: enduro-world-series-return-innerleithen-summer
story: ELITE athletes from across the world are set toto Peeblesshire for a mountain bike festival this summer.The Enduro World Serieswas held in Innerleithen last year following a six-year hiatus.And organisers want the event – which reportedly brought , people to the area last time out – to be “even bigger” this year.Event director Emma Wadee said: “We can’t wait to bring EWS back to Innerleithen this summer.“Our aim is to build on last year’s success to make EWS Tweed Valley one of Scotland’s best international events that celebrates the region and local community, as well as attracting visitors from around the world.”Organisers say it will be a “weekend of racing, entertainment, live music, local food, kids events, ride outs, film nights and more”.The festival is due toon June  until June  this year.Businesses and residents will receive communications about the event in the coming weeks, including letters and packs.Meanwhile there is a planned ‘town hall’ event on Thursday, April  in the Union Club.As well as attracting some of mountain biking’s top athletes, the festival could also give Peeblesshire businesses a major boost.Ahead of last year’s event, council officers said that the biking spectacle could have an “economic impact of £.m for the area”.Meanwhile, Enduro Sports Organisation – the company behind the EWS – is set to open its global headquarters in Innerleithen later this year.It follows an extensive renovation of a property on the town’s Chapel Street.From there, its growing team will coordinate the global race series, which has mountain bike events in over  countries.

story: ParalympicsGB’s wheelchair curlers began their campaign at the Ice Cube with a closely contested - defeat to a strong Norway.The team of Hugh Nibloe, Gregor Ewan, Meggan Dawson-Farrell and Duns man David Melrose fought their way back from - down to tie the match before Norway took a decisive lead in the penultimate end.They had the chance to draw level with the last stone but it was not to be and Norway took the fixture.Later that day they faced a USA team who had also lost their opening match and it was another closely fought contest.USA raced in to a - lead then the momentum swung back and forth before a brilliant take out by Gregor Ewan gave ParalmypicsGB the lead for the first time in the penultimate end and they closed out the match to win -.The team were scheduled to face RPCtoday but that fixture was cancelled when the Russians were refused permission to take part.Afterwards Skip Hugh Nibloe said: ‘United States and Norway are good teams so to come out today won one and lost one is probably fair and it was so important to get that first win.“It was so important especially for Meggan and David being their first Paralympics to get that belief that we can win games and we know we are goGregor Ewan added: ‘USA is always a very hard match for us they never get a big win against us and we never get a big win against them“It’s always hard after a defeat but we went out for a push and got some fresh air before coming back in.“We have found getting moving and getting our brains in to gear helps – we have some games we are playing in the changing room just to try and keep us switched on“The round robin stage is never easy we know we need five to six wins to be close to qualying.
